title: Creatinine Clearance (Cockcroft-Gault Equation)
description: Estimates creatinine clearance for kidney function assessment and medication dosing using patient demographics and serum creatinine

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: Patient height in centimeters (optional, used for BMI calculation and weight adjustment recommendations)

ranges.interpretation: Normal creatinine clearance suggesting adequate kidney function for most medications
Mild kidney function impairment. Monitor closely and consider dose adjustments for renally eliminated drugs
Moderate kidney function impairment. Dose adjustments required for many medications
Severe kidney function impairment. Significant dose reductions or alternative medications required
End-stage kidney disease. Dialysis consideration and avoid nephrotoxic medications

references: Cockcroft DW, Gault MH. Prediction of creatinine clearance from serum creatinine. Nephron. 1976;16(1):31-41. doi:10.1159/000180580
Stevens LA, Coresh J, Greene T, Levey AS. Assessing kidney function--measured and estimated glomerular filtration rate. N Engl J Med. 2006;354(23):2473-2483.
Levey AS, Inker LA, Coresh J. GFR estimation: from physiology to public health. Am J Kidney Dis. 2014;63(5):820-834.
formula: CrCl (mL/min) = [(140 - age) × weight(kg) × (0.85 if female)] / (72 × serum creatinine mg/dL)
notes: Developed in 1973 by Cockcroft and Gault from 249 adult patients
Historically important but now largely superseded by CKD-EPI equations for GFR estimation
Still used for medication dosing in specific circumstances (e.g., DOACs, some antibiotics)
Tends to overestimate GFR by 10-20% compared to measured values
Less accurate at extremes of weight and in elderly patients
Assumes normal muscle mass and may be inaccurate in patients with altered muscle mass
Original formula derived from predominantly male population (96% male)
Consider using ideal body weight for obese patients or adjusted body weight
Not adjusted for body surface area unlike newer equations
May be preferred over eGFR for certain drug dosing decisions per regulatory guidance
Should be interpreted in clinical context with other assessments of kidney function
